Dear Paris Marie Miller:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
11/6/24, 11/8/24 and 11/12/24. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of
the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for
addressing residents' needs, implementation of
treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
The agency was found to be in non-compliance with the agency established staff
to youth ration. The agency policy indicates that the staff to youth ratio is 8:1. On
11/06/2024 the agency staffing was not in compliance with this policy.
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications
2

(1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall
not permit a child caring institution staff member to begin
working unless all of the following has been completed
using the forms, and in the manner, prescribed by the
department:
(a) A criminal record check as referenced in R
400.4113(f), including a fingerprint based check of
national crime information databases, unless an
alternative criminal history check has been
approved by the federal government.
Four of nine employee files reviewed failed to document completion of a criminal
history clearance as required prior to the start of employment.
CCI Rule 400.4132 Grievance procedures
(1) An agency shall have and follow a written grievance
handling procedure for residents and their families. All of
the following apply:
(a) The policy shall be provided to residents, their
families, and referring sources prior to or at
admission.
Two of three files reviewed failed to document that the grievance policy was
provided to residents and families at the time of admission.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(5) The social service supervisor shall approve,
countersign, and date the initial treatment plan.
One of three reports reviewed did not have a supervisor signature on the initial
treatment plan.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(4) The social service worker shall sign and date the
initial treatment plan.
Two of three cases reviewed did not have the signature of the social service
worker on the updated treatment plan.

CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
(5) The social service supervisor shall approve,

One of three cases reviewed did not have the signature of the supervisor on the

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• No technical assistance was provided to the agency.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was provided to the agency regarding job description and job duties
of the chief administrator. During the audit it was noted that the chief
administrator is also serving in the capacity of therapist and maintains a small
caseload. Review of the job description for chief administrator does not include
these duties and it was also noted that staffing does not include anyone to review
and sign off on reports written by the chief administrator when serving in this
capacity. Challenges associated with this arrangement were discussed with the
agency.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
The facility did not have any substantiated maltreatment in care cases during this
review period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
Special investigation 2024SIC0001816 was completed in December 2024. A
corrective action plan is required, and approval of the CAP is currently pending.
The agency has indicated a willingness to make the necessary revisions to attain
and maintain compliance relevant to the licensing rule 400.4127 - Staff to resident
ratio. (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct supervision
of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time
between the variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns noted after review of Universal Health Services
2023 annual report.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
4

N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was received and reviewed. The assessment
indicates there were not any major barriers or systemic factors impacting rule
compliance. The agency is currently in the process of an overhaul of the manner in
which residents are educated. The Chief Administrator has expressed her
commitment to making the necessary adjustments to meet the educational and
overall needs of residents.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Havenwyck staff were interviewed on November 6, 2024. Staff expressed
concerns regarding staffing shortages, however shared that they believed that the
agency was making appropriate attempts to address the matter. No additional
concerns were noted or expressed.
Youth were interviewed on November 6, 2024 and November 8, 2024. Youth
spoke positively about the agency staff and overall programing. In addition, youth
reported feeling safe and nurtured at the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency was completed on November 6, 2024 and November
8, 2024. No areas of concern were noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
